metadata.title: Facile one-pot fabrication of nano-Fe3O4/carboxyl-functionalized baker’s yeast composites and their application in methylene blue dye adsorption

Applied Surface Science
journa l h om epa ge: www.elsev ier .com/ locate /apsusc
acile one-pot fabrication of nano-Fe3O4/carboxyl-functionalized aker’s yeast composites and their application in methylene blue dye dsorption
ongjun Dua,1, Yue Zhanga,1, Zhengjie Lia, Hui Chenb, Ying Wangc, Guangtu Wangd, ing Zoud, Huaping Chend, Yunsong Zhangd,∗
Department of Aquaculture, Sichuan Agricultural University, Wenjiang, 611130, PR China College of Life, Sichuan Agricultural University, Yaan 625014, PR China College of Conservancy and Hydropower Engineering, Sichuan Agricultural University, Yaan 625014, PR China College of Science, Sichuan Agricultural University, Yaan 625014, PR China
r t i c l e i n f o
rticle history: eceived 16 June 2016 eceived in revised form 1 September 2016 ccepted 12 September 2016 vailable online 14 September 2016
a b s t r a c t
Nano-Fe3O4/carboxyl-functionalized baker’s yeast composites (NF/CF-BYs) were prepared for the first time based on the ultrasonic cavitation assisted oxygen implosion method using single Fe2+ as iron source. The series of characterization analysis results showed that the obtained NF/CF-BYs had not only the superparamagnetic properties of nano-Fe3O4, but their surface also had plenty of functional groups (especially carboxyl groups) introduced by strong oxidization. The adsorption properties of NF/CF-BYs
eywords: ltrasonic cavitation ano-Fe3O4 aker’s yeast dsorption ethylene blue
for methylene blue (MB) were also evaluated. The results displayed that the uptakes of NF/CF-BYs for MB were higher than that of pristine baker’s yeast (P-BYs), and the adsorption process was followed by the pseudo-second-order kinetic model and Langmuir isotherm. The maximum adsorption capacity of NF/CF-BYs for MB was estimated to be 141.75 mg g−1 at pH 6. The regeneration efficiency of the obtained NF/CF-BYs was attained to be more than 90%.
© 2016 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
. Introduction
Methylene blue (MB) as an effective antifungal dyes, which an effectively prevent and cure Trichodiniasis, Saprolegniasis, chthyophthiriasis and other fish diseases, has been widely applied n aquaculture industry [1,2]. However, owing to the mutagenic and arcinogenic effects, difficult degradation and poisonousness, MB an caused harms to humans and animals especially aquatic biota 3,4]. Till now, various technologies were proposed and employed or treatment of dye wastewater, including adsorption, chemical xidation, ion-exchange, membrane filtration, etc. [5–7]. Among hem, adsorption has received increasing attention in recent years ecause it is low-cost, effective and simple for water purification.
Baker’s yeast as the industrial microorganism has widely been pplied into biosorbents studies for wastewater treatment due o its safe, useful and cheap properties [8,9]. Nevertheless, it is ell known that yeast cell wall mainly consists of polysaccharides
∗ Corresponding author. E-mail address: yaanyunsong@226.com (Y. Zhang). 1 These authors contributed equally to this work.
ttp://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.apsusc.2016.09.050 169-4332/© 2016 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
(glucan and mannose), which have insufficient active functional groups on its surface, thus often leading to dissatisfactory wastewater treatment effect. To introduce more active functional groups, surface functionalization/modification of yeast was generally carried out, e.g., ethanol/caustic-pretreatment, polymer modification [10,11]. However, small size of yeast cell results in the obstacle of separation and recycle from solution, which limits its application in water treatment.
The magnetic separation technique has gotten considerable attention because of its high solid-liquid phase separation efficiency [12]. Nano-Fe3O4, which has super-paramagnetic properties, has been widely used for purifying waste-water from dying industry, removing heavy metals and applicating photocatalytic degradation [13–15]. Up to now, nano-Fe3O4 has typically been prepared by using both ferrous (Fe2+) and ferric (Fe3+) ions as iron sources in alkaline conditions [16,17], and there were few reports on employing single Fe2+/Fe3+ ions to synthesize nano-Fe3O4 [18].
Herein, on the basis of the studies on the oxidative degradation of saccharides and their derivatives for achieving organic carboxylic acids [19,20], and the intense local temperature (5000 K) and huge instantaneous pressure (1800 atm) in liquids caused by ultrasonic cavitation [21–23], we report a facile and eco-friendly route to
of NF
p p i d s t t t t f g c o n c s r d f F c a o b
2
2
w r d s y P
C M f f
2
o 2 w 3
Scheme 1. Preparation mechanisms
repare nano-Fe3O4/carboxyl-functionalized baker’s yeast comosites (NF/CF-BYs) via the ultrasonic cavitation assisted oxygen
mplosion method using single Fe2+ as iron source in alkaline conitions, and explore their adsorption performance of MB in aqueous olution. As illustrated in Scheme 1, Fe2+ ions were first adsorbed on he baker’s yeast surface, and then the adsorbed Fe2+ were oxidized o Fe3+ ions with hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) solution. Subsequently, he excessive H2O2 was further added dropwise under ultrasonicaion. On account of the remarkable catalysis characteristic of Fe3+ or H2O2 [24], H2O2 decomposed violently, and the resultant oxyen bubbles constantly imploded and produced strong ultrasonic avitation effect, which not only supplied large energy to strongly xidize the polysaccharides in yeast cell wall for producing more umber of carboxyl groups on their surface, but also damaged yeast ell walls exposing more functional groups. Moreover, the ultraonic cavitation effect caused the generation of abundant hydroxyl adicals (·OH) with high reactivity [25,26], which can further oxiize the yeast cell wall. Finally, certain amount of Fe2+ solution was urther added into the above-mentioned suspension, and nanoe3O4 was in-situ achieved on yeast surface in alkaline and stirring ondition. As a result, by reason of more carboxyl groups exposed nd superparamagnetic nano-Fe3O4 loaded on yeast surface, the btained NF/CF-BYs will display higher adsorption capacity and etter recycle properties than pristine baker’s yeast (P-BYs).
. Experimental
.1. Materials and reagents
Baker’s yeast, supplied by Angel yeast Ltd., China, was first ashed with ultrapure water to remove the dirt and soluble impuities. After the suspension was centrifuged at 4000 r min−1, the eposit biomass was collected and dried at 80 ◦C for 24 h and then crunched and sieved to a particle size of 100 meshes. Finally, the east was stored in a desiccator. The purified yeast was denoted as -BYs.
MB was purchased from Tianjin Chemical Reagent No. 1 plant, hina. A stock solution of MB was prepared by dissolving 1.0 g of B into 1 L of ultrapure water. The working solutions were diluted
rom the aforementioned stock solution. Other reagents purchased rom Kelong Corp., China, were analytical grade.
.2. Preparation of NF/CF-BYs
NF/CF-BYs were prepared by ultrasonication cavitation assisted xygen implosion method using single Fe2+ as iron source. First, 0 mL of FeCl2·4H2O (1.25 mol L−1) and 5 g of dry P-BYs sample ere mixed and agitated on a rotary shaker (DH2-DA, China) for 0 min at 150 rpm. Then 10 mL of H2O2 solution (30%) was added
/CF-BYs and MB adsorption process.
with oscillation for 20 min, and the excessive 25 mL of H2O2 solution (30%) was further added dropwise into the resulting mixture under ultrasonication (400 W, 30 min). After no oxygen bubbles generating, 10 mL of FeCl2·4H2O (1.25 mol L−1) and 5 mL of NaOH (0.1 mol L−1) were transferred into the above mentioned mixture successively under vigorous stirring. Finally, the obtained products (NF/CF-BYs) were magnetically separated and repeatedly washed several times with ultrapure water until the pH of solution was close to 7.0, followed by vacuum-dried at 60 ◦C for 24 h.
2.3. Characterization
The morphology of P-BYs and NF/CF-BYs were researched by scanning electron microscopy (SEM, JSM-7500F, Japan) equipped with an EELS spectrometer (EDX, EX-350, Japan). The magnetism of NF/CF-BYs was recorded using a digital camera (EOS 760D, Japan). The crystalline forms and elementary composition were studied by X-ray diffraction (XRD, DX-2600, China) and Energy-dispersive Xray (EDX, X-Max 51-XMX0019, Britain). The magnetic properties of samples were detected by using a vibrating sample magnetometer (VSM, 7340, Lakeshore, America). Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (Shimadzu FTIR-8400S, Japan) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, XSAM800, Britain) was applied to examine the functional groups of two adsorbents surface. The surface charges were acquired by Zeta potential analysis (Malvern-Zetasizer nano ZS, UK) during pH range 3.0–8.0.
2.4. Adsorption experiments
Batch adsorption researches were conducted in 250 mL conical flasks at different pH (2.0–8.0), contact time (5–120 min), temperatures (25, 35 and 45 ◦C) and initial MB concentration (50–500 mg L−1). Briefly, 30 mL of MB solution at different initial concentration was shaken at 150 rpm in a rotary shaker with 0.1 g dry sample for a required adsorption time at varying pH values. Afterwards, the mixture was separated by a permanent magnet. The concentration of MB was analyzed by using UV-vis-NIR spectroscopy (Hitachi U-4100, Japan) with the max at 664 nm. The MB adsorption capacity (qe) was calculated by the following equation:
qe = (Ce − C0)Vm (1)
where qe is the amount of adsorption capacity at equilibrium (mg g−1), Ce is the MB concentration at time (mg L−1), C0 is the initial concentration MB (mg L−1), V is the volume of the solution (L) and m is the mass of adsorbent (g).

.5. Adsorption isotherms
The isotherms were acquired by a similar adsorption experient. Tests were conducted for 60 min. The adsorption capacity
f two adsorbents for MB solution was studied at different iniial concentrations (50–500 mg L−1, pH 6) at 35 ◦C. The adsorption sotherms for MB solution by P-BYs and NF/CF-BYs were described y Langmuir, Freundlich, and Temkin, respectively [27].
The Langmuir model isotherm is applicable to monolayer dsorptions and can be expressed as:
Ce qe = Ce qm + 1 bqm
(2)
here Ce is the equilibrium MB concentration in the solution mg L−1), qe is the equilibrium MB solution concentration on the dsorbent (mg g−1), qm is the maximum monolayer adsorption apacity of the adsorbent (mg g−1) and b is the Langmuir adsorption quilibrium constant (L mg−1) related to the free energy and affinty of adsorption. To determine whether the adsorption is favorable, n equilibrium parameter RL is investigated based on Langmuir sotherm, and could be expressed as:
L = 1
1 + bC0 (3) here b is the Langmuir constant (L mg−1) and C0 is the initial B concentration (mg L−1). The values of RL forecast the isotherm hapes, which can be unfavorable (RL ≥1) or favorable (0 ≤ RL ≥ 1). The Freundlich isotherm based on adsorption in a heterogeeous surface is described as follows:
og qe = log KF + 1 n log Ce (4)
here KF is a constant relating the adsorption capacity and 1/n is n empirical parameter correlating the adsorption intensity, which lters with the heterogeneity of the material.
The Temkin isotherm is described by the following equation:
e = RT ln(KT Ce) (5)
bT here R is the universal gas constant (8.314 J mol−1), T is the
bsolute temperature, bT is the variation of adsorption energy J mol−1), KT is the Temkin equilibrium binding constant (L mg−1).
ow the high-magnification SEM images of P-BYs and NF/CF-BYs, respectively. SEM
The Temkin constants can be obtained from the plot of qe versus lnCe.
2.6. Specific surface area
The specific surface areas of P-BYs and NF/CF-BYs were investigated by methylene blue method [28,29]. Typically, 0.1 g of each adsorbent was added into 30 mL of methylene blue solution with different concentrations. After stirring for 1 h, the residual methylene blue concentration was measured by UV–vis-NIR spectroscopy, which can be calculated as follows [30]:
S = XmAmN M
(6)
where S is the specific surface area (m2 g−1), Xm is the amount of adsorbed MB in the monolayer (mg g−1), N is Avogadro constant (6.02 × 1023), Am is the area occupied by per MB molecule (10−2 nm2), M is the MB molar mass (373.89 g mol−1).
2.7. Desorption and regeneration studies
In order to assess the reversibility of MB sorption for NF/CFBYs, adsorption/desorption experiments have been carried out. Desorption studies were carried out in 250 mL conical flasks. The MB-loaded NF/CF-BYs, which were separated by a permanent magnet from dyes solution with MB concentration of 300 mg L−1 at pH 6, 35 ◦C after adsorption experiments, were eluted with 0.1 mol L−1 HCl. Then, the suspension was shaken at 150 rpm for 30 min to allow MB to release from NF/CF-BYs. The MB regeneration experiment was investigated and the MB adsorption capacity was calculated. Finally, the desorbed MB was analyzed and the MB recovery efficiency was calculated as follows [31]:
Desorption efficiency(%) = Desorbed concentration Adsorbed concentration × 100% (7)

.1.1. SEM, specific surface area and elemental mapping analysis The SEM images of P-BYs and NF/CF-BYs are shown in Fig. 1. ig. 1a describes the P-BYs cells, which are oval and individual with he length of ca. 6.0 m and width of ca. 4.0 m. Moreover, the high
agnification image (inset in Fig. 1a) further displays that the PYs cells surface are smooth. After ultrasonic cavitation treatment,
t is observed that the cell surfaces of yeast become rough (Fig. 1b). dditionally, the high magnification image (inset in Fig. 1b) furher presents that nano-Fe3O4 particles are loaded on yeast surface. eanwhile, Fig. 1c, Fig. 1b and Fig. 1d show the SEM mapping mages of NF/CF-BYs with the distribution of carbon (C), oxygen O) and iron (Fe) element on their surface, respectively which conrmed the even formation of magnetic iron oxide particles on yeast urface. Furthermore, the specific surface area analysis indicated hat NF/CF-BYs had larger specific surface area than P-BYs (Table 1), urther implying that the yeast cell micro-morphology is changed, nd NF/CF-BYs are successfully prepared by the ultrasonic cavitaion assisted oxygen implosion method.
.1.2. EDX and XRD analysis The EDX pattern of P-BYs and NF/CF-BYs are shown in Fig. 2. wo adsorbents mainly include C, O and N elements with differnt intensities indicating that the yeast cell walls mainly consist f polysaccharides and proteins. After ultrasonic cavitation prepaation (Fig. 2b), the intensities of two peaks of C and O on yeast ell walls obviously increased, and Fe element was found in NF/CFYs, further suggesting that the polysaccharides on yeast cell walls ere oxidized, and nano-Fe3O4 was successfully in-situ loaded on F/CF-BYs surface.
Fig. 3 shows the XRD patterns of NF/CF-BYs and P-BYs. P-BYs as a broad strong peak, nevertheless, NF/CF-BYs not only possess he diffraction pattern of P-BYs, but also show few well-defined eaks of Fe3O4. The formation of a strong peak at 2 = 35.82◦ (311), hereas weak peak positions at 2 = 30.42◦ (220), 43.40◦ (400),
57.42◦ (511), 62.86◦ (440) displayed that the nano-Fe3O4 particles were successfully synthesized on yeast surface [32,33].
3.1.3. VSM analysis The magnetic properties of Fe3O4 and NF/CF-BYs are characterized by VSM at room temperature, and the magnetic hysteresis loops are shown in Fig. 4. It can be found that the magnetic saturation (Ms) values of Fe3O4 and NF/CF-BYs were 48.26 emu g−1 and 13.08 emu g−1, respectively. The decrease of Ms for NF/CF-BYs compared with Fe3O4 can be attributed to the low content of iron oxide in unit weight sample [15]. Moreover, the magnetic separation ability was tested in aqueous solution by placing a permanent magnet (inset in Fig. 4.). From the photograph, it can be clearly seen that NF/CF-BYs could be easily collected by magnetic separation, implying that NF/CF-BYs are good at magnetic reclamation after removal of MB.
3.1.4. FTIR, XPS, and zeta potentials analysis The FTIR spectrum of P-BYs (Fig. 5) includes the stretching vibration of −NH/-OH groups at 3288.4 cm−1 and a C O stretching vibration from carboxyl groups at 1392.5 cm−1. Meanwhile, there are three dominant amide I (1672.8 cm−1), amide II (1531.2 cm−1) amide III (1236.2 cm−1) peaks, which reveal that the protein also exists in yeast cells [34,35]. All of these results show that the functional groups on pristine yeast surface mainly are hydroxyl,
c o 1 l a o a m a a w 6 f o
t 2 t i i t C fi o [ i
arboxyl, and amine. Compared with P-BYs, some changes occurred n NF/CF-BYs (Fig. 5). The two new peaks at 2825.0 cm−1 and 224.7 cm−1 come from the stretching band of C O in carboxyates, respectively. Moreover, the new weak peaks at 1164.9 cm−1 nd 902 cm−1 deriving from the stretching band of C N in fatty secndary amine, and the stretching band of N H in primary amine lso appear. Obviously, these results indicated that the glucan and annose were oxidized, and more number of carboxyl groups were chieved on yeast surface. Moreover, due to yeast cell walls damged by the ultrasonic cavitation process, more functional groups ere exposed. Both the peaks at low-frequency region around 25.3 cm−1 and 459.2 cm−1 are ascribed to the Fe-O vibrations rom nano-Fe3O4 [36,37], which further confirmed the existence f nano-Fe3O4 particles on yeast surface.
The C 1s XPS spectra of two adsorbents (Fig. 6a and b) contained hree main peaks with binding energy of around 284, 286 and 87 eV, which correspond to C C/C H, C O and O C O, respecively [31,38]. The concentration of O C O in NF/CF-BYs (Fig. 6b) s 13.94%, lower than that (11.06%) in P-BYs (Fig. 6a) indicating the ncrease in carboxyl groups on yeast surface by ultrasonic caviation effect. Meanwhile, NF/CF-BYs have lower concentration of
O (26.77%) compared with P-BYs (28.64%), which further conrmed that the ultrasonic cavitation effect can cause the oxidation f alcoholic hydroxyl groups in polysaccharides on yeast cell wall 39,40]. Additionally, the Fe 2p XPS spectra on NF/CF-BYs are shown n Fig. 6c. The peaks at 711.9 and 725.1 eV are attributed to Fe 2p3/2
agnetic response (inset) of NF/CF-BYs before (left) and after (right) adsorption.
and Fe 2p1/2 in Fe3O4, respectively [41], which also confirmed nano-Fe3O4 formation on yeast surface.
The results of Zeta potentials analysis for P-BYs and NF/CF-BYs (Fig. 6d) indicated that all their Zeta potentials decreased with the increase of pH due to the deprotonation of carboxyl groups on two adsorbents. The pHZCP of P-BYs and NF/CF-BYs were about 4.52 and 4.63, respectively. At pH <4.63, NF/CF-BYs had positive charge, which might decrease the electrostatic attraction between carboxyl groups and MB. Conversely, after pH >4.63, NF/CF-BYs had more negative charges than P-BYs owing to more amounts of carboxyl groups on NF/CF-BYs surface, which can effectively improve the electronegativity of NF/CF-BYs, thus facilitating MB adsorption [42,43]
3.2. Adsorption experiment
3.2.1. The effect of pH The pH of adsorption solution plays an important role in researching the adsorption capacity of adsorbent. The effect of pH on MB adsorption capacity for P-BYs and NF/CF-BYs were studied at different pH values from 2.0 to 8.0. As seen in Fig. 7, with the increase of pH values, there was a sharp increase of adsorption capacity on two adsorbents and then reach equilibrium, which should be attributed to more H+ competing with MB for binding sites on adsorbents surface at lower pH condition [31]. At higher pH, NF/CF-BYs surface might become more negatively charged. The increase of electrostatic adsorption force between NF/CF-BYs and MB resulted in the enhancement of MB adsorption capacity [44]. The adsorption capacity reached equilibrium when the pH was above 6, which might be ascribed to saturation of adsorption sites on adsorbent surfaces. Additionally, the maximum adsorption capacity of NF/CF-BYs for MB (141.75 mg g−1) is about 2.69 times higher than that of P-BYs (52.65 mg g−1), which indicated that larger numbers of functional groups (carboxyl, amine, etc.) exposed on NF/CF-BYs were beneficial to enhancing their adsorption capacity for MB [45].
3.2.2. The contact time and kinetic studies The effect of adsorption time (5–120 min) for MB by P-BYs and NF/CF-BYs were investigated at 35 ◦C, pH 6.0 with the concentration of 300 mg L−1. As shown in Fig. 8a, the two adsorbents displayed the increasing adsorption trend up to the contact time of 15 min, and the adsorption processes quickly approached equilibrium. Moreover, the phenomenon of higher adsorption capacity by NF/CF-BYs further indicate that ultrasonic cavitation effect can not only cause the oxidation of polysaccharides in yeast cell for
g c w

enerating more number of carboxyl groups but also damage yeast ell walls for exposing more functional groups on their surface, hich are in favour of the adsorption towards MB. In order to

analyze the adsorption kinetics of MB on P-BYs and NF/CF-BYs, the pseudo-first-order and pseudo-second-order kinetic models were studied [33,46].
qt = qe(1 − e−k1t) (8)
qt = k2q 2 e t

where qt and qe are the adsorption capacity of MB at time t and equilibrium (mg g−1), respectively. k1 is the constant rate of pseudo-first-order adsorption (g mg−1 min−1), k2 is the constant rate of pseudo-second-order adsorption (g mg−1 min−1).
The kinetic curves of P-BYs and NF/CF-BYs were manifested in Fig. 8b and c, and the corresponding kinetic parameters were listed in Table 2. For P-BYs, the correlation coefficient values (R2) of pseudo-first-order model (R2 = 0.9299) was lower than the pseudosecond-order model (R2 = 0.9894), and the calculated adsorption capacity value (qe,cal = 52.72 mg g−1) for pseudo-second-order was approximate to experimental values (qe,exp = 51.12 mg g−1). As for NF/CF-BYs, the correlation coefficient (R2 = 0.9925) of the pseudo-second-order model was also higher than that of the pseudo-first-order model (R2 = 0.8327) and the calculated value

tion models were used to fit the data, namely Langmuir, Freundlich and Temkin. The isotherm parameters for MB adsorption were summarized in Table 4. Apparently, Langmuir adsorption isotherm qe,cal = 135.59 mg g−1) for pseudo-second-order was close to the xperimental value (qe,exp = 133.02 mg g−1). The results indicated hat the adsorption processes of P-BYs and NF/CF-BYs for MB were etter fitted to the pseudo-second-order model.
3.2.3. The thermodynamic studies The adsorption thermodynamics is an important factor to consider, because it helps to designing better adsorption parameters and benefits to understanding the possible mechanism of adsorption. The thermodynamics behaviors at 25 ◦C, 35 ◦C and 45 ◦C were studied by the following equations, respectively [47]:
G0 = −RT ln KC (10)
ln KC = S0 R − H 0 RT (11)
where G0 is the Gibbs free energy change in the given process (kJ mol−1), R is the gas constant (8.314 J mol−1 k−1), T is the temperature in K and KC is the equilibrium constant. S0 is the entropy change and H0 is the enthalpy change.
As presented in Table 3, the G0 values were negative at all three temperatures, displaying that the adsorption of MB on two adsorbents was spontaneous in nature. The value of G0 decreased with increasing temperature, which suggested that higher temperature was more advantageous to the thermodynamics perspective [48,49]. The H0 value of NF/CF-BYs and P-BYs were calculated as −3.74 kJ mol−1 and −9.99 kJ mol−1, respectively, which indicated the endothermic adsorption process for the two adsorbents. Meanwhile, the positive value of S0 forecasted that the adsorption process increased the randomness at the solid-solution interface. The entropy was positive, but the overall free energy was still negative. All of these implied that the adsorption process was mainly driven by the entropy effect [50].
3.2.4. The initial MB concentrations and adsorption isotherms The initial MB concentrations also are worth of the concerned parameters in evaluating the influencing factors on adsorption process. As seen in Fig. 9a, the adsorption capacity was improved tempestuously in the first stage with initial concentrations of MB increasing, and then attained a platform. The reasons might be the increased electrostatic attraction between carboxyl groups on yeast surface and MB with increasing initial concentration of MB. The result is similar to the previous reports [51].
To further analyze the adsorption data, three isothermal adsorp-
was better to describe MB adsorption process on P-BYs and
F (
N F w a s o M n o

t
ig. 9. Effect of initial MB concentrations (a), and different isotherm models of P-BYs b) and NF/CF-BYs (c) for MB adsorption.
F/CF-BYs, respectively, the nonlinear fitting curves are given in ig. 9b and c. Besides, both of the calculated RL values (Table 4) ere in the range of 0–1, further displaying the conformity of two dsorbents for MB adsorption. More importantly, NF/CF-BYs posess higher adsorption capacity for MB compared with P-BYs and ther reported adsorbents (Table 5). The possible reason for higher B adsorption capacity on NF/CF-BYs should be attributed to more umber of functional groups (such as carboxyl and amine) exposed n yeast surface.
.3. Desorption and regeneration studies
The regeneration of the adsorbent is an important facor in assessing its possibility for practical application. The
adsorption/desorption cycles of MB were repeated thrice using eluent of 0.1 mol L−1 HCl, and the MB-loaded NF/CF-BYs was separated by a permanent magnet. Fig. 10 reveals that no obvious change in the adsorption capacity and desorption efficiency of NF/CF-BYs for MB occurred after three consecutive adsorption/desorption cycles, indicating that NF/CF-BYs is an effective and reusable adsorbent. The relative stable adsorption capacity implied that the synthesized NF/CF-BYs can be effectively reused in the wastewater treatment.
4. Conclusions
In summary, NF/CF-BYs were successfully fabricated for the first time based on the ultrasonic cavitation assisted oxygen implosion method using single Fe2+ as iron source. The adsorption isotherms could be well fitted by the Langmuir isotherm model, and the adsorption process could be well described by pseudosecond-order kinetics. The characterization results of SEM, element mapping, EDX, XRD, VSM, FTIR, XPS and Zeta potential analysis indicated that the nano-Fe3O4 were successfully loaded on the surface of baker’s yeast, and the higher MB adsorption capacity of NF/CFBYs should be attributed to more functional groups exposed on yeast surface. Additionally, the regeneration experiments also indicated that NF/CF-BYs possess a predominant recycle property in MB adsorption process. Therefore, the obtained NF/CF-BYs should have a great promising application in wastewater treatments.
Acknowledgements
We acknowledge support from the Basic Research Program of the Science &Technology Department of Sichuan Province, PR China (Grant No. 2015SZ0102; 2011ZR0067) and the Key Basic Research Program of the Sichuan Provincial Education Commission, PR China (Grant Nos. 10ZB034). Sincerely thanks to anonymous reviewers for helpful suggestions.

metadata.abstractText: Nano-Fe3O4/carboxyl-functionalized baker’s yeast composites (NF/CF-BYs) were prepared for the first time based on the ultrasonic cavitation assisted oxygen implosion method using single Fe2+ as iron source. The series of characterization analysis results showed that the obtained NF/CF-BYs had not only the superparamagnetic properties of nano-Fe3O4, but their surface also had plenty of functional groups (especially carboxyl groups) introduced by strong oxidization. The adsorption properties of NF/CF-BYs eywords: ltrasonic cavitation ano-Fe3O4 aker’s yeast dsorption ethylene blue for methylene blue (MB) were also evaluated. The results displayed that the uptakes of NF/CF-BYs for MB were higher than that of pristine baker’s yeast (P-BYs), and the adsorption process was followed by the pseudo-second-order kinetic model and Langmuir isotherm. The maximum adsorption capacity of NF/CF-BYs for MB was estimated to be 141.75 mg g−1 at pH 6. The regeneration efficiency of the obtained NF/CF-BYs was attained to be more than 90%. © 2016 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
metadata.creator: Elsevier
